medical: REASON FOR ADMISSION: Hepatic encephalopathy. HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: The patient is a 51-year-old Native American male with known alcohol cirrhosis who presented to the emergency room after an accidental fall in the bathroom. He said that he was doing fine prior to that and denied having any complaints. He was sitting watching TV and he felt sleepy. So, he went to the bathroom to urinate before going to bed and while he was trying to lift the seat, he tripped and fell and hit his head on the back. His head hit the toilet seat. Then, he started having bleeding and had pain in the area with headache. He did not lose consciousness as far as he can tell. He went and woke up his sister. This happened somewhere between 10:30 and 11 p.m. His sister brought a towel and covered the laceration on the back of his head and called EMS, who came to his house and brought him to the emergency room, where he was found to have a laceration on the back of his head, which was stapled and a CT of the head was obtained and ruled out any acute intracranial pathology. On his lab work, his ammonia was found to be markedly elevated at 106. So, he is being admitted for management of this. He denied having any abdominal pain, change in bowel habits, GI bleed, hematemesis, melena, or hematochezia. He said he has been taking his medicines, but he could not recall those. He denied having any symptoms prior to this fall. He said earlier today he also fell. He also said that this was an accidental fall caused by problem with his walker. He landed on his back at that time, but did not have any back pain afterwards. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Liver cirrhosis caused by alcohol. This is per the patient. 2. He thinks he is diabetic. 3. History of intracranial hemorrhage. He said it was subdural hematoma. This was traumatic and happened seven years ago leaving him with the right-sided hemiparesis. 4. He said he had a seizure back then, but he does not have seizures now. PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: 1. He has a surgery on his stomach as a child. He does not know the type. 2. Surgery for a leg fracture. 3. Craniotomy seven years ago for an intracranial hemorrhage/subdural hematoma. MEDICATIONS: He does not remember his medications except for the lactulose and multivitamins. ALLERGIES: Dilantin. SOCIAL HISTORY: He lives in Sacaton with his sister. He is separated from his wife who lives in Coolidge. He smokes one or two cigarettes a day. Denies drug abuse. He used to be a heavy drinker, quit alcohol one year ago and does not work currently. FAMILY HISTORY: Negative for any liver disease. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: GENERAL: Denies fever or chills. He said he was in Gilbert about couple of weeks ago for fever and was admitted there for two days. He does not know the details. ENT: No visual changes. No runny nose. No sore throat. CARDIOVASCULAR: No syncope, chest pain, or palpitations. RESPIRATORY: No cough or hemoptysis. No dyspnea. GI: No abdominal pain. No nausea or vomiting. No GI bleed. History of alcoholic liver disease. GU: No dysuria, hematuria, frequency, or urgency. MUSCULOSKELETAL: Denies any acute joint pain or swelling. SKIN: No new skin rashes or itching. CNS: Had a seizure many years ago with no recurrences. Left-sided hemiparesis after subdural hematoma from a fight/trauma. ENDOCRINE: He thinks he has diabetes but does not know if he is on any diabetic treatment. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: VITAL SIGNS: Temperature 97.7, heart rate 83, respiratory rate 18, blood pressure 125/72, and saturation 98% on room air. GENERAL: The patient is lying in bed, appears comfortable, very pleasant Native American male in no apparent distress. HEENT: His skull has a scar on the left side from previous surgery. On the back of his head, there is a laceration, which has two staples on. It is still oozing minimally. It is tender. No other traumatic injury is noted. Eyes, pupils react to light. Sclerae anicteric. Nostrils are normal. Oral cavity is clear with no thrush or exudate. NECK: Supple. Trachea midline. No JVD. No thyromegaly. LYMPHATICS: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. HEART: Normal S1 and S2. No murmurs or gallops. Regular rate and rhythm. ABDOMEN: Soft, distended, nontender. No organomegaly or masses. LOWER EXTREMITIES: +1 edema bilaterally. Pulses strong bilaterally. No skin ulcerations noted. No erythema. SKIN: Several spider angiomas noted on his torso and upper extremities consistent with liver cirrhosis. BACK: No tenderness by exam. RECTAL: No masses. No abscess. No rectal fissures. Guaiac was performed by me and it was negative. NEUROLOGIC: He is alert and oriented x2. He is slow to some extent in his response. No asterixis. Right-sided spastic hemiparesis with increased tone, increased reflexes, and weakness. Increased tone noted in upper and lower extremities on the right compared to the left. Deep tendon reflexes are +3 on the right and +2 on the left. Muscle strength is decreased on the right, more pronounced in the lower extremity compared to the upper extremity. The upper extremity is +4/5. Lower extremity is 3/5. The left side has a normal strength. Sensation appears to be intact. Babinski is upward on the right, equivocal on the left. PSYCHIATRIC: Flat affect. Mood appeared to be appropriate. No active hallucinations or psychotic symptoms. LABORATORY DATA: White count 4, hemoglobin 14.2, hematocrit 40.2%, platelets 85,000, PT is 13.4, INR is 1, BUN 7.8, glucose 105, sodium 141, potassium 3.9, bicarbonate 22.3, calcium 8.7, albumin 3.6, AST 39, ALT 27, alkaline phosphatase 140, total bilirubin is 0.9, and ammonia level is 106. IMAGING STUDIES: CT of the head. Film was reviewed. The report mentioned, status post frontal craniotomy and a small focus of encephalomalacia involving the left frontal lobe. This is likely consistent with residuals from his previous head injury. There is also mild generalized atrophy and changes consistent with chronic small vessel disease. No other findings on his CT. The skull is unremarkable except for the surgery changes. No acute abnormalities overall. ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 1. Hepatic encephalopathy. Trigger is unclear at this time. Could be noncompliance. No evidence of GI bleed and his electrolytes are normal. I am not sure if he is taking any sedatives, as he does not recall the medication that he is on. The patient will be admitted to the hospital for management. He will be started on lactulose. I will give him 30 mL every two hours until he has a bowel movement. Then, we will adjust the dose to target three bowel movements daily and we will monitor his ammonia level and ensure that it is trending down. We will monitor his electrolyte and correct as needed and I will hydrate him, as hypovolemia is also a possible trigger. We will obtain an ultrasound of his abdomen to see if there is any ascites. At this time, there is no clinical evidence of SBP, but if he develops any fever may consider tapping his belly if there is ascites to rule out that possibility. 2. Thrombocytopenia likely due to cirrhosis. We will monitor the level. No need for transfusion at this time. 3. Macrocytosis also due to liver disease. I will check his vitamin levels, however, to ensure that he does not need any supplementation. 4. History of diabetes as per the patient. His glucose is 105. This can be clarified in the morning with his primary care physician. We will monitor his glucose for now. 5. Skull laceration. This was stapled by the ER physician and we will watch it for now, appear to be stable. No evidence of any other trauma. 6. We will watch him on the telemetry floor to ensure that he has no arrhythmias leading to his two falls, which appear to be incidental as per the patient. 7. Right-sided hemiparesis appear to be chronic and not an acute issue. The patient already has a walker at home. 8. We can try to obtain more information in the morning about his past medical history, medication, etc., from his family and/or his primary care physician at Sacaton. Time spent in evaluation and management of this patient in the emergency room exceeds 70 minutes.
layman:
**REASON FOR ADMISSION**  
The patient was admitted because of hepatic encephalopathy (a brain problem caused by liver disease).

**HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS**  
A 51‑year‑old Native American man with a known history of alcohol‑related liver cirrhosis came to the emergency department after falling in his bathroom. He said he was fine before the fall and had no complaints. While watching TV he felt sleepy, went to the bathroom to pee, and when he tried to lift the toilet seat he tripped, fell, and hit the back of his head on the toilet seat. He started bleeding, felt pain, and had a headache. He did not lose consciousness. He woke his sister, who covered the cut with a towel and called EMS. EMS brought him to the ER between 10:30 and 11 p.m. The ER found a cut on the back of his head, stapled it, and performed a head CT that showed no new brain bleed. Blood tests showed a very high ammonia level of 106 µmol/L, which is why he is being admitted. He denied abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, vomiting blood, black or bloody stools, or any other symptoms before the fall. He said he has been taking his medications but cannot remember them. He also mentioned a previous accidental fall earlier that day caused by a problem with his walker; he landed on his back but had no back pain afterward.

**PAST MEDICAL HISTORY**  
1. Alcohol‑related liver cirrhosis (patient’s own statement).  
2. He thinks he has diabetes.  
3. History of a traumatic brain bleed (subdural hematoma) seven years ago, which left him with weakness on the right side of his body.  
4. He had a seizure at that time but has not had seizures since.

**PAST SURGICAL HISTORY**  
1. Stomach surgery as a child (type unknown).  
2. Surgery for a leg fracture.  
3. Craniotomy (brain surgery) seven years ago for the subdural hematoma.

**MEDICATIONS**  
He can only remember taking lactulose and multivitamins. He does not recall any other drugs.

**ALLERGIES**  
Dilantin (phenytoin).

**SOCIAL HISTORY**  
Lives in Sacaton with his sister. Separated from his wife who lives in Coolidge. Smokes 1–2 cigarettes a day. No drug abuse. He used to drink heavily but stopped drinking a year ago. He is not working.

**FAMILY HISTORY**  
No family history of liver disease.

**REVIEW OF SYSTEMS**  
- **General:** No fever or chills. He was in a hospital in Gilbert a few weeks ago for fever and stayed two days (details unknown).  
- **ENT:** No vision changes, runny nose, or sore throat.  
- **Cardiovascular:** No fainting, chest pain, or palpitations.  
- **Respiratory:** No cough, no coughing up blood, no shortness of breath.  
- **Gastrointestinal:** No abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or bleeding. He has a history of alcoholic liver disease.  
- **Genitourinary:** No painful urination, blood in urine, frequent or urgent urination.  
- **Musculoskeletal:** No new joint pain or swelling.  
- **Skin:** No new rashes or itching.  
- **Central Nervous System:** Had a seizure many years ago; no current seizures. He has right‑side weakness from a past brain bleed.  
- **Endocrine:** He thinks he has diabetes but is not sure if he is on treatment.

**PHYSICAL EXAMINATION**  

*Vital Signs* – Temperature 97.7 °F, heart rate 83 bpm, respiratory rate 18/min, blood pressure 125/72 mm Hg, oxygen saturation 98 % on room air.  

*General* – He is lying in bed, looks comfortable, pleasant, and not in distress.  

*Head, Eyes, Ears, Nose, Throat (HEENT)* – He has a scar on the left side of his skull from previous surgery. The back of his head has a cut with two staples; it is still oozing a little and is tender. No other injuries. Eyes are normal, pupils react to light, no yellowing of the whites. Nose and mouth are normal.  

*Neck* – Flexible, trachea in the middle, no jugular vein swelling, no enlarged thyroid.  

*Chest* – Lungs clear to listening.  

*Heart* – Normal heart sounds, no murmurs, regular rhythm.  

*Abdomen* – Soft, a little distended, not tender, no enlarged organs or masses.  

*Lower Extremities* – Mild swelling on both legs, good pulses, no skin sores or redness.  

*Skin* – Several spider‑like blood vessels on the torso and arms, typical of liver cirrhosis.  

*Back* – No tenderness.  

*Rectal* – No masses or fissures; stool test negative for blood.  

*Neurologic* – Alert and oriented to person and place. Slower than usual responses. No tremor. He has right‑side spastic weakness: increased muscle tone, higher reflexes, and weaker muscles on the right. Right arm strength 4/5, right leg strength 3/5. Left side normal. Sensation intact. Babinski sign up on the right, unclear on the left.  

*Psychiatric* – Flat affect, mood appropriate, no hallucinations or psychosis.  

**LABORATORY DATA**  
White count 4 × 10⁹/L, hemoglobin 14.2 g/dL, hematocrit 40.2 %, platelets 85 000 /µL, PT 13.4 s, INR 1.0, BUN 7.8 mg/dL, glucose 105 mg/dL, sodium 141 mEq/L, potassium 3.9 mEq/L, bicarbonate 22.3 mEq/L, calcium 8.7 mg/dL, albumin 3.6 g/dL, AST 39 U/L, ALT 27 U/L, alkaline phosphatase 140 U/L, total bilirubin 0.9 mg/dL, ammonia 106 µmol/L.

**IMAGING STUDIES**  
Head CT: shows old changes from a previous frontal craniotomy and a small area of brain tissue loss in the left frontal lobe, likely from the old injury. Mild brain shrinkage and small vessel disease changes are present. No new problems.

**ASSESSMENT AND PLAN**  

1. **Hepatic encephalopathy** – The cause is unclear; it could be due to not taking medications or another trigger. No evidence of a stomach bleed and electrolytes are normal. He is admitted for treatment.  
   - Start lactulose 30 mL every 2 hours until a bowel movement occurs. Then adjust to aim for 3 bowel movements per day. Monitor ammonia levels to see if they go down.  
   - Check electrolytes and give fluids if needed because low blood volume can worsen the problem.  
   - Order an abdominal ultrasound to look for fluid in the belly (ascites). If he develops a fever, we may need to tap the belly to rule out infection (spontaneous bacterial peritonitis).  

2. **Low platelets (thrombocytopenia)** – Likely from liver disease. Monitor; no transfusion needed right now.  

3. **Large red blood cells (macrocytosis)** – Common with liver disease. Check vitamin levels to see if supplements are needed.  

4. **Possible diabetes** – His blood sugar is 105 mg/dL. We will confirm with his primary doctor and monitor for now.  

5. **Head cut** – Stapled in the ER and looks stable. Watch it for any changes.  

6. **Heart rhythm** – Keep him on telemetry to watch for arrhythmias that might explain his falls.  

7. **Right‑side weakness** – Chronic from the old brain bleed; not an acute issue. He already uses a walker at home.  

8. **Gather more information** – In the morning we will talk to his family and his primary care doctor in Sacaton to clarify his past medical history and medications.  

The time spent evaluating and managing this patient in the emergency department was over 70 minutes.
